title: Malaysian SEA GYPSIES brave treacherous waters to catch DANGEROUS mantis shrimp
text:
Malaysian SEA GYPSIES brave treacherous waters to catch DANGEROUS mantis shrimp Malaysian SEA GYPSIES brave treacherous waters to catch DANGEROUS mantis shrimp IT'S not often we get an up-close and personal view of the fishing traditions of the Malaysian sea gypsies. PUBLISHED: 10:51, Thu, Oct 22, 2015 | UPDATED: 11:08, Thu, Oct 22, 2015 CATERS Malaysian fishermen have been pictured catching mantis shrimp 
A photographer has shared a set of incredible images with the world, giving us an insight into the lives of Malaysian sea gypsies. 
Underwater production company Scubazoo travelled to the village to learn more about this unusual way of fishing as part of their 'Borneo from Below' online series. Related articles Sun, sea and swimming with dolphins: Mexico is holiday top spot... 
They met one of the local Bajau Laut or 'sea gypsies', called Minayak to document him catching mantis shrimp. 
Presenter and photographer Aaron 'Bertie' Gekoski, 35 from London accompanied Minayak on one of his fishing trips and managed to capture some stunning shots. 
Bertie said: "Catching mantis shrimp is not for the faint of heart and requires persistence and skill. CATERS The mantis shrimp is one of the most feared crustaceans because of its strength 
"Mantis shrimp is a popular dish in the region and the shrimps have been caught using traditional fishing methods for a long time, which are incredibly targeted and non-destructive compared to other local practices such as fish bombing or cyanide." 
The traditional fishermen use a simple but ingenious method to capture one of the most violent underwater creatures in the world: mantis shrimps. 
The shrimps have arm spears or clubs that can accelerate with the same velocity as a gunshot - and at its peak, the force is over 2,500 times the animal's body weight. 
To earn a living, the people in the fishing village of Semporna, on the eastern coast of Malaysian Borneo, use four tools - fishing line, bamboo, rock and bait - to capture the volatile shrimps. CATERS The mantis shrimp is literally stunning with its bright colours 
The technicolour crustaceans have even been known to smash through aquarium glass and diver's goggles. 
Despite their violent ways, they are commonly served in restaurants throughout Asia - often prepared as sushi or deep fried and served with chilli and garlic. 
Once they're caught, in the sea, the stunning animals are wedged into bottles to be transported to an aquarium. 
Earnings for the sea gypsies are slim, with each shrimp selling to restaurants for the equivalent of 50 pence. On a very good day, 10-20 can be caught. 
The unusual method uses a fishing line which is turned into a noose and fastened to a piece of bamboo, which has bait skewered onto it, like a kebab. 
The construction is then put in the mantis's burrow, so that the bait tempts the mantis towards the opening. 
The other end of the fishing line is attached to a heavy object, such as a rock, so that when the mantis takes the bait the fishing line tightens around it. The more it struggles, the tighter the hold. 
Then a tug of war breaks out as the fisherman pulls the mantis out of its burrow.
